They work great. Good clean definition with low noise. Now I can adjust the stereo spread in the mix. Can't get a better rig for $200. Please try again later.Seph5.0 out of 5 stars Great value Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2012Style: GXL3000Verified Purchase This mic is much heavier than I expected, which is a good thing. i think it will take quite the beating.The sound quality is fantastic on vocals and acoustic instruments. The selectable cardioid patterns, HP filter, and pad selection are a rarity at this price range, not to mention the decent quality shock mount included.I assume if you are shopping for a condenser mic you already know this, but just in case... All condenser mics require phantom power, so make sure your mixer/interface/etc supply it, otherwise it won't work.Also, my inexperience of patterned mics made it slightly confusing to figure out where the 'front' of the mic was. If you position it with the pattern selection switch directly facing you (or the source of sound) that is the 'front.' I assume now that this is standard positioning, however I couldn't speak to other mics. When in doubt, just record a quick test, turning it 90 or 180 degrees and see which sounds 'right' when you have it set to reject sounds from the rear.I do wish it came with a better case, like my MXL-603 small diaphragm mics came with. The leather (or pleather, not sure right now) case is ok, but provides no real protection from drops, and doesn't house the shock mount, just the mic itself. At this price though, I can't take away a star for that.This mic is well worth the standard asking price, and if you find it on sale like I did, snatch it up! Read more 7 people found this helpful Helpful Report abuse Huncy5.0 out of 5 stars Great Mic, Great company to order from. Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2020Style: GXL3000Verified Purchase I’ve been using a CAD pencil mic for years on Acoustic guitar. I checked out some reviews on the CAD Multi-pattern Condencer mic and gave it a try. Love it on OMNI for gang vocals. I used the customer service for a problem, I was answered back quick, and they solved the problem the first time. Read more Helpful Report abuse Andrew Darovich1.0 out of 5 stars The polar pattern switch doesn't work. Junk. Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2020Style: GXL3000Verified Purchase Brand new, fresh out of the box, and the polar pattern switch to use omni/bi/cardioid polar patterns does absolutely nothing. It switches, the mic does nothing for about 5 seconds and then it goes right back into being omnidirectional. Completely useless as a cardioid condenser mic for vocals.Sound quality is no better than a Shure SM58, and those are half the price. Hard pass. Good thing I can return it and get something that's not a piece of crap. Read more Helpful Report abuse MBondy5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect sound capture Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2020Style: GXL1200Verified Purchase Bought this after testing several more expensive mics and was very impressed at how it captured the tone and characteristics of my Guild Jumbo Acoustic. This CAD mic sounded even better than my $1200.00 AKG414!Would definitely suggest you at least give it a try. Read more Helpful Report abuse Brian T. Clem5.0 out of 5 stars Bought one last year... so good that I bought two more.... Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2009Style: GXL1200Verified Purchase These are used in an elementary school cafeteria. They are hung so that they pickup 1/3 of the stage. One mic did such a great job, I bought two more. Now I have complete coverage that produces such a clear and transparent sound image of the action on stage. I also had Rode mics and a few others but quickly found out that nothing came close to this mic. The other mics have their place as they perform well in other situations... but these pencil mics just did the trick in my case. I would completely recommend these for over-head mic'ing. Read more One person found this helpful Helpful Report abuse John H4.0 out of 5 stars Low cost condenser mic Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2010Style: GXL1200Verified Purchase I use this mic is used primarily for micing acoustic guitar or mandolin at small coffee house type gigs. The sound is quite good, and its sensitivity allows the instrument to be some distance from the mic, which can be handy if you're trying to mic several instruments at once from one mic. I have another mic of this size, an SE-1, and the two are comparable. I've not had any problems with mine, and would buy another if this one were to disappear (which sometimes happens at gigs!) Read more 2 people found this helpful Helpful Report abuse Alex M. Cox5.0 out of 5 stars Hot little mic. Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2021Style: GXL1200Verified Purchase This is one hot little mic. It picks up the choir perfectly. Just what we needed and at a great price. Read more Helpful Report abuse Simon C Webb5.0 out of 5 stars Nice mic for the price Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2020Style: GXL1200Verified Purchase Works great for my needs Read more Helpful Report abuse See all reviews Top reviews from other countries M. Lamb5.0 out of 5 stars Quality professional microphone Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 22, 2017Style: GXL3000Verified Purchase Quality heavy duty Microphone. Bought for my new Internet Radio station and not disappointed. Sounds clear and professional and comes with a shock mount which is good quality too. Please try again later.Seph5.0 out of 5 stars Great value Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2012Style: GXL3000Verified Purchase This mic is much heavier than I expected, which is a good thing. i think it will take quite the beating.The sound quality is fantastic on vocals and acoustic instruments. The selectable cardioid patterns, HP filter, and pad selection are a rarity at this price range, not to mention the decent quality shock mount included.I assume if you are shopping for a condenser mic you already know this, but just in case... All condenser mics require phantom power, so make sure your mixer/interface/etc supply it, otherwise it won't work.Also, my inexperience of patterned mics made it slightly confusing to figure out where the 'front' of the mic was. If you position it with the pattern selection switch directly facing you (or the source of sound) that is the 'front.' I assume now that this is standard positioning, however I couldn't speak to other mics. When in doubt, just record a quick test, turning it 90 or 180 degrees and see which sounds 'right' when you have it set to reject sounds from the rear.I do wish it came with a better case, like my MXL-603 small diaphragm mics came with. The leather (or pleather, not sure right now) case is ok, but provides no real protection from drops, and doesn't house the shock mount, just the mic itself. At this price though, I can't take away a star for that.This mic is well worth the standard asking price, and if you find it on sale like I did, snatch it up! Please try again later.Seph5.0 out of 5 stars Great value Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2012Style: GXL3000Verified Purchase This mic is much heavier than I expected, which is a good thing. i think it will take quite the beating.The sound quality is fantastic on vocals and acoustic instruments. The selectable cardioid patterns, HP filter, and pad selection are a rarity at this price range, not to mention the decent quality shock mount included.I assume if you are shopping for a condenser mic you already know this, but just in case... All condenser mics require phantom power, so make sure your mixer/interface/etc supply it, otherwise it won't work.Also, my inexperience of patterned mics made it slightly confusing to figure out where the 'front' of the mic was. If you position it with the pattern selection switch directly facing you (or the source of sound) that is the 'front.' I assume now that this is standard positioning, however I couldn't speak to other mics. When in doubt, just record a quick test, turning it 90 or 180 degrees and see which sounds 'right' when you have it set to reject sounds from the rear.I do wish it came with a better case, like my MXL-603 small diaphragm mics came with. The leather (or pleather, not sure right now) case is ok, but provides no real protection from drops, and doesn't house the shock mount, just the mic itself. At this price though, I can't take away a star for that.This mic is well worth the standard asking price, and if you find it on sale like I did, snatch it up! Clem5.0 out of 5 stars Bought one last year... so good that I bought two more.... Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2009Style: GXL1200Verified Purchase These are used in an elementary school cafeteria. They are hung so that they pickup 1/3 of the stage. Seph5.0 out of 5 stars Great value Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2012Style: GXL3000Verified Purchase This mic is much heavier than I expected, which is a good thing. i think it will take quite the beating.The sound quality is fantastic on vocals and acoustic instruments. The selectable cardioid patterns, HP filter, and pad selection are a rarity at this price range, not to mention the decent quality shock mount included.I assume if you are shopping for a condenser mic you already know this, but just in case... All condenser mics require phantom power, so make sure your mixer/interface/etc supply it, otherwise it won't work.Also, my inexperience of patterned mics made it slightly confusing to figure out where the 'front' of the mic was. If you position it with the pattern selection switch directly facing you (or the source of sound) that is the 'front.' I assume now that this is standard positioning, however I couldn't speak to other mics. When in doubt, just record a quick test, turning it 90 or 180 degrees and see which sounds 'right' when you have it set to reject sounds from the rear.I do wish it came with a better case, like my MXL-603 small diaphragm mics came with. The leather (or pleather, not sure right now) case is ok, but provides no real protection from drops, and doesn't house the shock mount, just the mic itself. At this price though, I can't take away a star for that.This mic is well worth the standard asking price, and if you find it on sale like I did, snatch it up! Andrew Darovich1.0 out of 5 stars The polar pattern switch doesn't work. Junk. Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2020Style: GXL3000Verified Purchase Brand new, fresh out of the box, and the polar pattern switch to use omni/bi/cardioid polar patterns does absolutely nothing. It switches, the mic does nothing for about 5 seconds and then it goes right back into being omnidirectional. Completely useless as a cardioid condenser mic for vocals.Sound quality is no better than a Shure SM58, and those are half the price. Hard pass. Good thing I can return it and get something that's not a piece of crap. Read more Helpful Report abuse

John H4.0 out of 5 stars Low cost condenser mic Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2010Style: GXL1200Verified Purchase I use this mic is used primarily for micing acoustic guitar or mandolin at small coffee house type gigs. The sound is quite good, and its sensitivity allows the instrument to be some distance from the mic, which can be handy if you're trying to mic several instruments at once from one mic. I have another mic of this size, an SE-1, and the two are comparable. I've not had any problems with mine, and would buy another if this one were to disappear (which sometimes happens at gigs!) The sound is quite good, and its sensitivity allows the instrument to be some distance from the mic, which can be handy if you're trying to mic several instruments at once from one mic.  I have another mic of this size, an SE-1, and the two are comparable.  I've not had any problems with mine, and would buy another if this one were to disappear (which sometimes happens at gigs!)
  
Read more
